items.body_markdown:
I have 4-dimensional data, say for the temperature, in an `numpy.ndarray`. 
The shape of the array is `(ntime, nheight_in, nlat, nlon)`.

I have corresponding 1D arrays for each of the dimensions that tell me which time, height, latitude, and longitude a certain value corresponds to, for this example I need `height_in` giving the height in metres.

Now I need to bring it onto a different height dimension, `height_out`, with a different length.

The following seems to do what I want:

    ntime, nheight_in, nlat, nlon = t_in.shape

    nheight_out = len(height_out)
    t_out = np.empty((ntime, nheight_out, nlat, nlon))

    for time in range(ntime):
        for lat in range(nlat):
            for lon in range(nlon):
                t_out[time, :, lat, lon] = np.interp(
                    height_out, height_in, t[time, :, lat, lon]
                )

But with 3 nested loops, and lots of switching between python and numpy, I don't think this is the best way to do it.

Any suggestions on how to improve this? Thanks
items.title: Best way to interpolate a numpy.ndarray along an axis
items.body:
I have 4-dimensional data, say for the temperature, in an numpy.ndarray. The shape of the array is (ntime, nheight_in, nlat, nlon).

I have corresponding 1D arrays for each of the dimensions that tell me which time, height, latitude, and longitude a certain value corresponds to, for this example I need height_in giving the height in metres.

Now I need to bring it onto a different height dimension, height_out, with a different length.

The following seems to do what I want:

ntime, nheight_in, nlat, nlon = t_in.shape

nheight_out = len(height_out)
t_out = np.empty((ntime, nheight_out, nlat, nlon))

for time in range(ntime):
    for lat in range(nlat):
        for lon in range(nlon):
            t_out[time, :, lat, lon] = np.interp(
                height_out, height_in, t[time, :, lat, lon]
            )

But with 3 nested loops, and lots of switching between python and numpy, I don't think this is the best way to do it.

Any suggestions on how to improve this? Thanks

items.title: Using UnityMvc with a Repository with Constructor
items.body:
I am trying to build an application which, based on user interaction, returns either the context of a TestDB or of the ProductionDB. Originally I simply used two Repositories with the same Functions, but that seems to be a somewhat "ugly" way to solve this.

Now I have only one Repository with a constructor which accepts a string-value (env) which is used to identify the DB the user wants to access:

using System;
using System.Collections.Generic;
using System.Linq;
using System.Text;
using System.Threading.Tasks;
using Webfrontend004601.Core.Interfaces;
using Webfrontend004601.Core.Models;
using Webfrontend004601.ViewModels;

namespace Webfrontend004601.Infrastructure.Repositories
{

    /// <inheritdoc/>
    public class ParameterRepository : IParameterRepository
    {
        /// <summary>
        /// Domäne der DB, auf die zugegriffen werden soll
        /// </summary>
        public enum Environment { ITestF, Prod }
        private readonly AddonContext _context;

        /// <summary>
        /// Wird benötigt zur Unterscheidung des Datenbankzugriffs
        /// </summary>
        /// <param name="env"></param>
        public ParameterRepository(string env)
        {
            switch (env)
            {
                case "ITestF":
                    _context = ContextFactory.AddonDbTest;
                    break;
                case "Prod":
                    _context = ContextFactory.AddonDbProd;
                    break;
                default:
                    throw new ArgumentOutOfRangeException(nameof(env), env, null);
            }
        }
        ...
    }
}

And here is the Factory that helps initiating the Connection.

/// <summary>
    /// Dient der Generierung des DB-Contexts
    /// </summary>
    public static class ContextFactory
    {

        /// <summary>
        /// Gibt den Connectionstring der gewünschten Datenbank zurück
        /// </summary>
        /// <param name="env">Domäne der DB, auf die zugegriffen werden soll</param>
        /// <returns></returns>
        private static SqlConnection GetConnectionString(ParameterRepository.Environment env)
        {
            switch (env)
            {
                case ParameterRepository.Environment.ITestF:
                    return new SqlConnection(ConfigurationManager.ConnectionStrings["AddonITestF"].ConnectionString);
                case ParameterRepository.Environment.Prod:
                    return new SqlConnection(ConfigurationManager.ConnectionStrings["AddonProd"].ConnectionString);
                default:
                    throw new ArgumentOutOfRangeException(nameof(env), env, null);

            }
        }
        public static AddonContext AddonDbTest => new AddonContext(GetConnectionString(ParameterRepository.Environment.ITestF));
        public static AddonContext AddonDbProd => new AddonContext(GetConnectionString(ParameterRepository.Environment.Prod));
    }

I tried to set the Repository inside of the Parameter-Constructor with a Session-variable which contains the environment, but that didn't work, because the Session is still null at that point. So I decided to override the OnActionExecuting()-Function instead:

protected override void OnActionExecuting(ActionExecutingContext filterContext)
{
    _db = new ParameterRepository((Session["Environment"].ToString()));
}

This works, but there are two setbacks:

  1. It's executed every time an Action inside of the Controller is being made.
  2. Unit-Testing doesn't work, because OnActionExecuting isn't executed. So the _db-Property ends up null.

Does anybody know a way to solve this problem more elegantly?

UPDATE

I got the Unit-Test to work, by adding an additional contructor to the Controller and changing the RegisterType-function a little bit.

        public static void RegisterTypes(IUnityContainer container)
    {
        container.RegisterType<IParameterRepository, ParameterRepository>(new InjectionConstructor("Prod"));
    }

That way I don't get an error which I would usually get, because the Repository-function has parameters. I do however still set the repository "properly" with OnActionExecuting as soon as the Session-variable is available.

    public ParameterController()
    {
    }

    public ParameterController(IParameterRepository db)
    {
        _db = db;
    }

Now I can use the constructor with parameter in my Unittest to set the repository.

There is however still the problem, that the Connection to the Database is set on each action.

    import pandas as pd

        old_g_counter = g_counter
        g_counter = g_counter + 1
        return old_g_counter * x

items.title: python pandas applying a function counter
items.body:
I'm trying to apply a function to a dataframe and i want to see how often the function i have applied was called. I could do this with a global variable but this seems to me not very elegant.

import pandas as pd

g_counter = 1

def how_often(x):
    global g_counter 
    old_g_counter = g_counter
    g_counter = g_counter + 1
    return old_g_counter * x

df = pd.DataFrame({'Hugo' : {'age' : 21, 'weight' : 75},
                   'Niklas': {'age' : 46, 'weight' : 65},
                   'Ronald' : {'age' : 76, 'weight' : 85, 'height' : 176}}).T
df.index.names = ['name']

df['counter'] = df['weight'].apply(how_often)

print (df)

I found a solution with the index from the constructor:

Python enumeration/row counter in a pandas column

but i want it independant from the index. Is there any built in function i could use ?

items.title: How to insert XML file data received from FTP in a table using XMLTABLE?
items.body:
So long story short, I receive XML files from an SFTP client and I need to store this data in an oracle database.

I'm currently deserializing the XML file and generating one large insert statement with all the values, but inserting this takes forever (30-50 minutes for 120000 rows).

I don't want to save the files on the server, so I'd rather use the FileStream data

Currently I read the XML files like this: 

using (SftpFileStream stream = sftp.OpenRead(filename))
{
    Xml.Process(stream);
}

So I want to try XMLTABLE to insert the XML file.

Let's say I didn't create a new table for the data yet and I received the stream data. I have the following XML file, which is called line.xml:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?>
<!--Created by a179-main 0.78.24-->
<cern:lines creationDate="2018-03-16T19:36:05" xmlns:cern="http://www.website.com" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.website.com ../ns/infrastructure.xsd">
   <cern:line id="10" validFromDate="1996-06-02" validToDate="2078-12-31"/>
   <cern:line id="11" validFromDate="1997-08-03" validToDate="2078-12-31"/>
   <cern:line id="12" validFromDate="1997-08-03" validToDate="2078-12-31"/>
</cern:lines>

How would I have to insert this into the database using XMLTABLE?
Also, what table columns do I create?
And is it possible to attach the stream or streamdata in the XMLTABLE statement?

Extra: I'm currently using Dapper as an ORM. Pretty much the same as ADO.NET, but a bit easier to read.

I have enabled one node with search and analytics through opscenter.

    :remote config alias g graphName.a

items.title: DSEGraphFrame impossible to launch the graph
items.body:
I have a dse graph in production.

I have enabled one node with search and analytics through opscenter.

I can successfully launch a gremlin console and run analytic queries with the command:

:remote config alias g graphName.a

The problem occurs when I try to launch a DSEGraph Frame query using the scala spark console.

Whenever I type the initial command in the scala spark console I got the same error.

val g = spark.dseGraph("graphName")

items.body_markdown:
How to catch numeric suffixes in filenames in makefile? More precisely, I have a book written in latex and split by multiple chapter files, I wanted to write a makefile that supports the following syntax, for compiling the whole book:

    make book
for individual chapter:

    make chapter_1
for example. My files are `book.tex` with several lines `\include{chapter_i}` and multiple number of `chapter_i.tex` files where `i` is a chapter number.

Thanks to all!
items.title: Generic filenames in Makefile
items.body:
How to catch numeric suffixes in filenames in makefile? More precisely, I have a book written in latex and split by multiple chapter files, I wanted to write a makefile that supports the following syntax, for compiling the whole book:

make book

for individual chapter:

make chapter_1

for example. My files are book.tex with several lines \include{chapter_i} and multiple number of chapter_i.tex files where i is a chapter number.

Thanks to all!
